Award.AwardTitle: A workshop proposal: Building US-China Collaboration in Biodiversity Studies - Frontier Issues, New Approaches, and Opportunities; North Carolina 10/9-11,2015; China 10/13-15, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a workshop in North Carolina and travel for U.S. researchers to a companion workshop in China to discuss recent advances and emerging areas in U.S.-China biodiversity research. The workshops will integrate keynote talks from invited speakers, mini-talks among participants in topical groups, discussion periods, and field trips. A diverse group of participants from the U.S. and China will include established scientists, junior researchers, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers from the fields of evolutionary biology, ecology, systematics, and bioinformatics. The involvement of individuals from under-represented groups will be prioritized during the selection process. Group discussions and field trips to coastal, freshwater swamp, and mountain ecosystems in North Carolina will foster broad and informal interactions that will facilitate new research directions and inspire new research collaborations.

The United States and China occupy large areas of North America and eastern Asia at similar temperate latitudes. The two regions offer many opportunities for comparative studies of biodiversity, from the origin, evolution, and distribution of species, to community assembly, ecosystem processes, ecological interactions, and sustainability. Workshop participants will include early career scientists, including postdocs and students, in discussions regarding the next generation of international biodiversity research and will involve participants from diverse disciplines and institutions. A website will be constructed to share information from the meeting including research talks, discussion summaries, and participant information. Outcomes from the meetings will also be disseminated broadly through presentations and exhibits at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, North Carolina State University, and The National Evolutionary Synthesis Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project achieved the main goals of running two US-China Biodiversity Workshops, one in Raleigh, NC and one in Hangzhou, China. The first meeting, entitled “Building US-China Collaboration in Biodiversity Studies – Frontier Issues, New Approaches, and Opportunities”” was held on Oct 15th – Oct 18th, 2015 at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. The meeting had 50 participants, including 21 participants from China.  The meeting included presentations, discussions, brainstorming sessions, and breakout groups to develop strategies and share information about collaborative efforts in biodiversity research in the US and China.  After the meeting, a three-day field trip to research sites in the southern Appalachian Mountains was conducted.  
The second meeting, entitled “China-US Biodiversity Workshop ---Building Sino-US Collaboration Platform in Biodiversity Studies - New Approaches and Theories" was held in Hangzhou China on Oct 19th - Oct 25th, 2016. The workshop included three days of presentation and discussion in Hangzhou and three days of field trip to research field sites in eastern China. There were 52 participants attended the meetings, with 18 traveling from the US.  A two-day symposium and discussion session was hosted at Zhejiang University with presentations from US and Chinese participants, question/answer sessions, and general group discussions. The workshop was attended by graduate students and postdocs from Zhejiang and local universities.

 

The project resulted in better understanding between US and Chinese scientists regarding their current research, and helped identify frontier issues and novel approaches for collaborative biodiversity research. The project facilitated new collaboration and strengthened existing collaborations through successfully connecting researchers from broad disciplines and approaches within biodiversity science. A social media connection and wiki was developed to manage and disseminate information from the workshop and beyond.  Plans were developed for continued collaboration, including plans for Research Coordination Network, development of joint training initiatives, and network for connecting researchers looking for new collaborations.

In summary, the project had brought a broad range of biodiversity researchers from China and US together to exchange ideas about on-going collaborative research, to present opportunities to researchers who are seeking partners to establish new collaborations, and to identify new, unique directions and questions for biodiversity study offered by the US-China collaboration.  Participants of both workshops included senior leading scientists, junior scientists, and graduate students in diverse fields of biodiversity research. The workshops included 29 graduate students and 6 postdocs. Students and postdocs were included in symposia, group sessions, informal breaks, social events and field trips.
